allReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    hardware as well is operating system overdone
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2024
allReviews.body: The Germans have a wonderful word concoction: "Verschlimmbessern"Meaning to improve something continuously and by that making gradually worse and eventually useless.In our "update mania" world this here is a classic case.The phone has a way to sensitive touchscreen and no matter what you try from the gazillion settings there is only one to increase the sensitivity but not to decrease it! You can search online that issue.Tests I did show that the touchscreen responds when the finger is actually is not touching the screen but is 0.5- 1mm ( 1/52" - 2/52") away from it!This leads of course to an absurd overreaction when you handle the phone, even with the palm protection on, it reacts unintentionally. Often even it responses before you have actually touched anything simply because you moved your finger without touching the screen!Then there is the OS, by now Android 14. Another effort to overload an overdo many functions and poorly organize them. all of course in the eternal other obsession "security". The [settings] interface is not intuitive and straightforward anymore like it used to be in older android OSs.Whereas like in earlier versions you could customize and prioritize which icon functions you wanted where, that no longer seems to be possible.And then of course the confirmation pop-up window mania.Say you want to turn something off or delete a message/email. You have to go on a regular basis through three confirmations! DUH? Say you select an email or SMS and click on delete, then it asks you first if you want to delete it, and then and then again were you wanted deleted to and finally you need to confirm that! Really? Seriously?notwithstanding that the new and improved absolutely outlandish privacy terms and all other terms all of them with their 10,000 links to other terms about terms and privacy etc. blah blah... I really feel being raped on a daily basis.Furthermore for some reason despite larger screen all the fonts are smaller but layout spacing is larger with more wasted space. (yes I tried the font sizing). Total useless another feature is, that you can choose from an endless variety of different fonts...Any app you start needs a gazillion confirmations requesting permission to give access to this and that, here and there etc. etc. Overall straightforward sensible layout of the interface and functionality is gone.Here's a personal comparison and experience.Before I upgraded to this phone I had a Samsung S5 with OS Android 6.01. Everything worked fine I never had an issue SMS and MMS sent out instantaneously and everything else worked. Of course with new apps the phone became, aside from artificial incompatibilities, slower and slower. P part of a marketing ploy probably.Now I have a Samsung A14 5G with Android 14. MMS take much longer and needs two or three confirmations...And when executing a functioning in an app, next time I open the app I have to navigate back as it doesn't go back like previously by default.There's more but that would take up too much space to writeup here.Remember the peaceful relaxed time when we had a Bell telephone and a typewriter?We were able to communicate and even managed to fly two men to the moon and bring them safely back...

allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2025
allReviews.body: Ok, so my mother-in-law (the technophobe) baby sits my 1 year old and has an old half broken prepaid flip phone that won't pick up a signal at our home. Truth be told all cell phone coverage is a blackhole at my house. It is in a rural location surrounded by hills. But I do have fiber internet and cell booster with AT&T that works great but you must have an AT&T phone to use it. So off to the AT&T Store we go. Long story short, I told them I needed a cheap phone for a technophobe and they tried to sell me an $800 phone (locked of course). Not no, but Hell No! So I ordered this, got it the next day. Yeah it's got a couple blemishes but once the protective case arrives tomorrow, they'll never be seen again. Took it to AT&T today and got it a sim card on my existing account for a mere 5 bucks and connected to the cell booster effortlessly, full bars (in blackhole). Even got her a 256 gb sandisk sd card for more storage than she'll probably ever need for $20 here on the 'zon. That math adds up to a mere $125, a damn sight better than $800 any day of the week.

allReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Fifth phone in my life, first to go defective after 2.5 foot drop
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
allReviews.body: I've previously had an LG and three Motorola phones. I'm not picky, so they've always been on the budget side. Always had to replace because of internal storage limitations and/or battery issues from long-term use. This time around, I decided to plunge for a budget-level Samsung, as I've enjoyed my experience with one of their GalaxyBooks over the last year. Loved the A14 5G at first, it's a major step-up for me in all of the specs. Or so I thought. After having it for six weeks, I just dropped it about 2.5 feet from counter to linoleum floor. Landed face down in a case, but I didn't think much of it as I've dropped old phones from much higher distances onto concrete and simply picked them up and kept going. Not so with this phone, whose screen went black and left me unable to interact with it. Force restart caused it to vibrate, so the internals are still working, but the screen is just dead. Never dropped it before, and never in my life have I had a phone screen quit on me, let alone after such a minor incident. After growing frustrated with lack of response and research that yielded there's probably nothing to do but replace the screen (which would cost more than I paid for this phone), I smacked the screen in frustration and wow - screen cracked. That's never happened to any phones I've owned, either, no matter the abuse I've handed them. Conclusion: back to Motorola I go!

allReviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Worse in virtually every way compared to my 2017 Moto x4. Keeping it due to longer software support
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2023
allReviews.body: I bought a Moto x4 many years ago and have been perfectly content with it. After it updated to Android 9 I didn't like the fact that you could no longer see all open apps in the new window-switching view, and it forced a google search toolbar, and a number of other things I thought were worse, so I used directions on xda to revert back to 8.1.I was perfectly happy with this for many years.Then a security-related app I was using notified me that Android 8.1 was not secure and has not received security updates for years. So I have to get the latest version of Android.Then I find out that Motorola doesn't publish security or Android version updates to the phone past Android 9, so my only option is to buy a new phone or flash a 3rd party ROM. I looked for instructions and ROMs, and LineageOS seemed to be the primary other option, but I ran into many problems.So I looked up what phones were similar to the Moto x4 and provided the longest term of security and software updates. Samsung Galaxy A14 5G seemed to be the winner so I bought it. It's 6 years newer than my Moto x4 so it should be an enjoyable upgrade at least right? Wrong.* It's much thicker and taller. Too tall for my liking; difficult to use with one hand - yes I've tested the "one-handed features".* The fingerprint reader is worse. The Moto x4's works 90%+ of the time, the A14's works about 40% of the time.* The battery takes many hours more (can be more than twice as long) to recharge (via USB 3.0 to my PC) and drains as fast or faster.* No call recording.* No view all open apps ability.* Various other annoyances related to how the software functions on this phone/android version.The only noticeable improvements are more customization of notifications & layout.New Android versions & phones are barely different and many of the changes are often downgrades. Hyping them up and making us buy new phones to get security updates is such a scam. My Moto x4 could have lasted me another decade at least.I hate the smartphone industry. Thankfully, California's new Right to Repair law might mostly solve this issue for the future.

allReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Is it worth it? You decide.
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2024
allReviews.body: I recently bought a phone from a different store from Amazon, and it really truly does look brand new. I decided I wanted to get another one for my fiance's birthday in August (I'm a horrible gifter and normally gift early or at the least plans months in advance). Well I was not so happy when I couldn't order from the original store the exact same device, so since this store did have a few in stock I took a chance and did this store instead. This store sold me the exact phone I wanted and there was only a $2 difference in price comparison to my original purchase, I also got the EXACT same quality I had ordered prior at the other store. I am not happy with the obvious picking marks from where they pride the previous screen off I assume, it is very noticable in a few areas of the phone along with a few indentions and a little bit of separation at the top. The indentions don't matter as much to me, but the obviously worked on glass has me questioning the quality on if it will hold up. Cheap phone? Yes. Doesn't work? Yes. Is it the most cosmetically pretty? No, But hey it's an upgrade that won't break bank. Id recommend they quality check better or decide on a new scale because the previous store with the exact same phone and wear for practically the same price, gave me a great nearly new device along with the original box and it had waaay better packaging and the phone still even had the film to protect the glass instead of a single piece of paper that this company has for "protection". We shall see how it does long term however. Luckily I bought a case and am gifting it ready to use so it does somewhat hide those damages, but if love chooses to put a different case on it may not be able to.

allReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Would not charge (had to return)
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2024
allReviews.body: I have an existing (purchased new unlocked) A14 and it works great.  I wanted a second one as a safe duplicate that would serve as my phone using a prepaid sims card for some travel.  The "renewed" phone looked great and everything worked fine after I copied over my existing phones data.  I could not test the actual calling feature, however, since I was going to buy the travel sims card while on vacation.  However turns out the phone would not charge at all.  (I did try all all the solutions on the internet and various cables and adaptors).  I am guessing they never really tested that in the "renewal" process. Ugh!  I am disappointed and just returned it (which is easy with Amazon).  I am going to try buying a used version of this phone again for my backup, and fingers crossed that it will work.  When it does work, the A14 is a nice capable phone.  Update - Amazon did made the return easy and prompt, and the second A14 phone works like brand new.  So one bad and one good phone in this process.  I guess a three star review.

It still downloaded UI 6 anyway since the first phone would not finish this update so I'm keeping my fingers crossed that any future updates aren't going to get locked again. allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Very nice budget phone
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2023
allReviews.body: This is a great budget phone. Sure higher end phones have better cameras, faster charging, and wireless charging. This phone's camera is plenty good for me and plugging in for a 15W charge is good enough for me. This phone has a large screen and large battery (some of Samsung's higher-end phones have smaller batteries). Samsung also promises longer upgrade support for higher end phones, but I didn't figure that spending twice as much for a phone with twice the ssoftware support period made for a better value.I did have trouble getting an actual Factory Unlocked phone (the first seller sent Carrier Unlocked versions of this phone instead of Factory Unlocked which could not be activated on my preferred carrier due to the carrier using a IMEI whitelist to check for compatibility). Factory Unlocked also means that I am not reliant on a carrier's software update channel (the AT&T carrier unlocked model's Android security patch level was still more than 6 months old after checking for updates - perhaps updates are only availably for that phone when on AT&T's network). In the future, I will check the seller's ratings and reviews before purchasing a refurbished Factory Unlocked phone (note that if the item is shipped by Amazon, the unit you get is not guaranteed to be the unit provided by the seller so checking the seller reviews is only useful for sellers who ship directly).

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Pleasantly Surprised
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
allReviews.body: This renewed Galaxy A14 G5 arrived unlocked as described.  It's renewed by Amazon and to be honest, I think it could possibly be brand new or as close as you can get.  There is literally not a mark or scuff on this phone.  It replaces an A02S Galaxy that I've had for a couple of years.  I'm a Tech guy so, it was pretty easy to set up.  I was able to install my Verizon SIM card and an additional 128Gb SDHC  memory card in about three minutes.  Downloaded the Samsung Smart Switch app from the Google Play store to both phones and within a few minutes, it transferred all my data and setup all the apps.  This was probably the longest part of the process consuming no more than 30 minutes.  Pretty much just had to set a few permissions and it was done.  It's fingerprint and facial recognition equipped. and the cameras seem pretty good.  As mentioned earlier, it IS Verizon compatible.  All in all, a pretty good phone at, what I think, is a fantastic price. UPDATE.....I moved this phone from Verizon to T-mobile without a single problem. Runs great using T-mobile's 5g. üëå

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    hardware as well is operating system overdone
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2024
criticalReviews.body: The Germans have a wonderful word concoction: "Verschlimmbessern"Meaning to improve something continuously and by that making gradually worse and eventually useless.In our "update mania" world this here is a classic case.The phone has a way to sensitive touchscreen and no matter what you try from the gazillion settings there is only one to increase the sensitivity but not to decrease it! You can search online that issue.Tests I did show that the touchscreen responds when the finger is actually is not touching the screen but is 0.5- 1mm ( 1/52" - 2/52") away from it!This leads of course to an absurd overreaction when you handle the phone, even with the palm protection on, it reacts unintentionally. Often even it responses before you have actually touched anything simply because you moved your finger without touching the screen!Then there is the OS, by now Android 14. Another effort to overload an overdo many functions and poorly organize them. all of course in the eternal other obsession "security". The [settings] interface is not intuitive and straightforward anymore like it used to be in older android OSs.Whereas like in earlier versions you could customize and prioritize which icon functions you wanted where, that no longer seems to be possible.And then of course the confirmation pop-up window mania.Say you want to turn something off or delete a message/email. You have to go on a regular basis through three confirmations! DUH? Say you select an email or SMS and click on delete, then it asks you first if you want to delete it, and then and then again were you wanted deleted to and finally you need to confirm that! Really? Seriously?notwithstanding that the new and improved absolutely outlandish privacy terms and all other terms all of them with their 10,000 links to other terms about terms and privacy etc. blah blah... I really feel being raped on a daily basis.Furthermore for some reason despite larger screen all the fonts are smaller but layout spacing is larger with more wasted space. (yes I tried the font sizing). Total useless another feature is, that you can choose from an endless variety of different fonts...Any app you start needs a gazillion confirmations requesting permission to give access to this and that, here and there etc. etc. Overall straightforward sensible layout of the interface and functionality is gone.Here's a personal comparison and experience.Before I upgraded to this phone I had a Samsung S5 with OS Android 6.01. Everything worked fine I never had an issue SMS and MMS sent out instantaneously and everything else worked. Of course with new apps the phone became, aside from artificial incompatibilities, slower and slower. P part of a marketing ploy probably.Now I have a Samsung A14 5G with Android 14. MMS take much longer and needs two or three confirmations...And when executing a functioning in an app, next time I open the app I have to navigate back as it doesn't go back like previously by default.There's more but that would take up too much space to writeup here.Remember the peaceful relaxed time when we had a Bell telephone and a typewriter?We were able to communicate and even managed to fly two men to the moon and bring them safely back...

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Fifth phone in my life, first to go defective after 2.5 foot drop
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I've previously had an LG and three Motorola phones. I'm not picky, so they've always been on the budget side. Always had to replace because of internal storage limitations and/or battery issues from long-term use. This time around, I decided to plunge for a budget-level Samsung, as I've enjoyed my experience with one of their GalaxyBooks over the last year. Loved the A14 5G at first, it's a major step-up for me in all of the specs. Or so I thought. After having it for six weeks, I just dropped it about 2.5 feet from counter to linoleum floor. Landed face down in a case, but I didn't think much of it as I've dropped old phones from much higher distances onto concrete and simply picked them up and kept going. Not so with this phone, whose screen went black and left me unable to interact with it. Force restart caused it to vibrate, so the internals are still working, but the screen is just dead. Never dropped it before, and never in my life have I had a phone screen quit on me, let alone after such a minor incident. After growing frustrated with lack of response and research that yielded there's probably nothing to do but replace the screen (which would cost more than I paid for this phone), I smacked the screen in frustration and wow - screen cracked. That's never happened to any phones I've owned, either, no matter the abuse I've handed them. Conclusion: back to Motorola I go!

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Is it worth it? You decide.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I recently bought a phone from a different store from Amazon, and it really truly does look brand new. I decided I wanted to get another one for my fiance's birthday in August (I'm a horrible gifter and normally gift early or at the least plans months in advance). Well I was not so happy when I couldn't order from the original store the exact same device, so since this store did have a few in stock I took a chance and did this store instead. This store sold me the exact phone I wanted and there was only a $2 difference in price comparison to my original purchase, I also got the EXACT same quality I had ordered prior at the other store. I am not happy with the obvious picking marks from where they pride the previous screen off I assume, it is very noticable in a few areas of the phone along with a few indentions and a little bit of separation at the top. The indentions don't matter as much to me, but the obviously worked on glass has me questioning the quality on if it will hold up. Cheap phone? Yes. Doesn't work? Yes. Is it the most cosmetically pretty? No, But hey it's an upgrade that won't break bank. Id recommend they quality check better or decide on a new scale because the previous store with the exact same phone and wear for practically the same price, gave me a great nearly new device along with the original box and it had waaay better packaging and the phone still even had the film to protect the glass instead of a single piece of paper that this company has for "protection". We shall see how it does long term however. Luckily I bought a case and am gifting it ready to use so it does somewhat hide those damages, but if love chooses to put a different case on it may not be able to.

criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I have an existing (purchased new unlocked) A14 and it works great.  I wanted a second one as a safe duplicate that would serve as my phone using a prepaid sims card for some travel.  The "renewed" phone looked great and everything worked fine after I copied over my existing phones data.  I could not test the actual calling feature, however, since I was going to buy the travel sims card while on vacation.  However turns out the phone would not charge at all.  (I did try all all the solutions on the internet and various cables and adaptors).  I am guessing they never really tested that in the "renewal" process. Ugh!  I am disappointed and just returned it (which is easy with Amazon).  I am going to try buying a used version of this phone again for my backup, and fingers crossed that it will work.  When it does work, the A14 is a nice capable phone.  Update - Amazon did made the return easy and prompt, and the second A14 phone works like brand new.  So one bad and one good phone in this process.  I guess a three star review.

criticalReviews.body: After doing much research and comparing other smartphones, I decided to purchase this based on very high scores, more features than I needed, and an affordable price. Within 2 weeks, I woke up around 1am and noticed the screen on the phone was on and thought it was doing an automatic update. After a good 10 to 20 minutes, the screen was still on and I'm thinking this shouldn't be on this long and when I checked it again is said error and the word SUPER which I had know idea what it meant. To make a long story short, it was frozen and I couldn't cancel or turn the thing off. I then took it to a local ATT&T just to check what was wrong and they referred me to call Samsung. After over an hour with tech support and going no where, I decided to return and get another one hoping I just got a lemon. So far, this new one is working and I changed the auto updates. It still downloaded UI 6 anyway since the first phone would not finish this update so I'm keeping my fingers crossed that any future updates aren't going to get locked again. For a phone that's only a little more than a year old better last for many years ore I'm going to morse code!!! Be aware what you get!

criticalReviews.body: Very, very slow. The touchscreen will frequently just not work. Frequently freezes for up to 15 seconds when opening the settings. No software installed outside of what came with it. Unclear if this was just a defective device being sold as refurbished to excuse the very laggy and broken behavior or if it had damaged components which weren't changed. Based on the other bad reviews, I cannot say for certain that these phones were obtained completely legally. Either way, you're being sold a bad product and it's being hidden from you by bought, obviously fake reviews.If, like me, you read reviews about it being scratched and a little busted but decide you might get the phone regardless because you just need a reasonably new device for development work and the price was the main point, I would still recommend avoiding it and not only from the ethics around the dubious sourcing. For my device (and it seems like many experience different problems), the performance was so bad that I could not effectively test on my device. It was always unclear where the fault lay.Spend a little bit more on a refurb somewhere else.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    More obnoxious than it's worth.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2023
criticalReviews.body: For reasons absolutely no tech support person anywhere could explain, there are inexplicable issues: carry-over, specifically relating to apps connecting and working between linked devices, which has frankly put a massive hitch in many of my everyday routines. I shopped for ages for a good deal, but this phone, maybe because it was used, is highly problematic for the few functions on it on which I rely. Autocorrect does not work. It does not remember frequently used words unless you misspell them. The screenshot function is useless and highly problematic. Certain apps just don't run. If you edit a photo, it immediately becomes "corrupted". Both the seller of this item and the manufacturer really botched their jobs with this one. I'm sure I'll find mpre problems as I use it. The moral is: don't truat Amazon to refurbish tech. Buy directly from a provider.
